turn.text: I believe Mr. Justice Brennan if there is anything to be said about that particular point, if we go so far as to say that federal government can make a non-discriminatory tax into a federal regulation, then I believe they have to take the burdens with the benefits.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then, you didn't answer my question.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes sir, it is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What would be duration of mandamus [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How would you get this equipment out there that the federal government asked to, how would you get it?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Oh!

I am sorry Mr. Justice Marshall, I believe that the idea if for instance customs had sealed off an area had bought a federal enclave and as they do in federal enclaves Mr. Justice Marshall, as at least in theory --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But it is no federal enclave?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No, it is not Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We are speaking about Long Beach.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you want Congress to take over Long Beach?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No Mr. Justice Marshall, I do not. [Attempt to Laughter]
The very idea though I think that if what I believe is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't know what you are talking about.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I am sorry Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you say this federal government has to give fire protection to Japanese containers in Long Beach.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that what you say?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: What I am saying is this sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that what you said?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I think I said that if the federal -- it is logical to do that if the federal government claims the privilege of immunizing a piece of property from tax which is the recoupment for those benefits and protections.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, can't we rule against you without all of that?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: You have to reach I believe Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Can't we?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: You have to reach the congressional power, you have to at least say that Congress can.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do we have to?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: If you rely on the enactments of the treaties.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We don't have to, can't you say so?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No sir, no sir of course not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, for you.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I am sorry, Mr. Justice Marshall.
I did not mean to anyway say that the Court had --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You said Congress had to.
You said Congress enforce the constitution and say that Long Beach cannot enforce this tax, but Congress will have to give the police fire and other protection.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I think under the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Don't you say it?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Logically under the federal system, yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's what you said.M

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let's assume that someone in New Jersey starts a steamboat line running up or a diesel would be today I suppose, a diesel running up the Hudson River and then it obviously make stops at Hudson River ports, can New York tax the diesel barges and vessels that are going from New Jersey up the Hudson.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I think only.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let's say they have exactly what we have got here can –

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: If they have a continuous presence in the taxing jurisdiction and I think that those benefits and protections are there then the tax I think automatically follows.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, now Gibbons against Ogden didn't involve the tax.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No sir, it did not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It involved the licensing, but you suggest that New York could tax New Jersey's diesel barges going up to Hudson, Pullman's Palace Cars.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Assuming what Pullman's Palace Car says Mr. Chief Justice, then the other side though too is that the regulation that's what Gibbons versus Ogden I think is all about.
It says first of all that you cannot regulate, you cannot prohibit that man from going up that river, but that you can tax it.
You can go out there and get a return for the benefits and protections conferred.
And I think that's true as long as the continuous presence and those benefits and protections are there.
I believe that in this case the continuous presence and the fact situation that we have here fully support and the appellants have not refuted that the benefits and protections are there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Clark, supposing that we were -- the President were to negotiate a treaty with Japan confirmed by the -- ratified by the Senate and Congress has implementing legislation under the interstate commerce power saying exactly what the treaty said that no property imported from Japan should ever be subjected to any state property tax so long as it was in existence, no matter how long it had been in this country, do you think it will be constitutional for Congress to do?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I have gotten into trouble with the Court on this.
I do not believe that that would be proper under the federal system.
I think --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you say proper did you think that would be constitutional for Congress to do that?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No sir it would not.

I think there are limitations on congressional authority and what I was getting to if I may emphasize this once again is that the logic of the federal system requires that if the federal government take the tax power away from the states, they must also have a responsibility before those benefits and protections which the state confers in one way or another.
Now that's the logic to me of the federal system and the relationship between those benefits and protections --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In fact --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You are urging that as an economic argument, advancing it that way or as a constitutional argument that there is a constitutional obligation to provide a substitute for the tax revenue?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice I think the constitutional argument is that there is no power in Congress to do that in the first place.
I speak, economically in the other terms.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you said they could it if they made the substitute provision?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I'm sorry Your Honor I meant to say if they could do it I believe that that would follow and I believe that is an economic argument following I think the federal relationship between the state and the federal government.
Mr. Justice Stevens?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I just want to be sure what you are suggesting here about the quid pro quo.
This is your idea, there are no cases that suggest this?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: No sir, they are not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I'm just wondering why you make the argument so strenuously.
It seems me you would be much tactically much better off to say yes Congress has all the power in the world, but hasn't exercised it?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Well, I think that quite frankly tactically that's, I'm sorry it is true, the enactment is not there.

Mr. Justice Stevens perhaps that is a luxury for those of us in public law have to strenuously urge those things which we feel are right and sound and perhaps that is where I am, but I believe that both arguments are quite correct.
I'm concerned, Mr. Justice Stevens, if the federal government has that power as to what is going to happen in terms of our federal system in terms of state and federal relationships.
I honestly believe that the states have a purpose and I say it has been constructed by probably correct interpretations of the commerce.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What might happen is that you won't be able to tax things, if you haven't been able to tax unless couple of hundred years?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: [Attempt to Laughter] Mr. Justice Stevens the idea of course is that they have not been here for a couple of 100 years. California has exercised I guess it is totally --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No the vessels have been coming and going and I think you stared earlier and saying these are just like vessels and I don't think you try to tax vessels for couple of hundred years?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Well, under California law we cannot.

The constitutional -- state constitutional provision which the appellants are alluded to has been interpreted as not corresponding with equal protection standards and therefore the exemption was applied by the Court to all vessels.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Clark, may I ask you an easier question?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Justice Powell.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: If we should affirm the decision of the California court, could the counter tax of the aircraft owned by foreign lands and based in foreign countries, but they use your airport?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: If the continuous presence is there, actually on the scheduled airlines I think that Ott versus Mississippi Barge Lines would go along with a regular presence as well as continuous, I would say yes.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The aircraft also use containers?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: They have their own interior containers which are however are not used in the same way as these containers, they are simply taken off the airplane, perhaps taken to the warehouse often unloaded directly at the airport and kept with the airplane itself.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But Mr. Clark you would say you could tax not only the containers but the aircraft itself?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Oh yes Mr. Justice Brennan I think there was a question to whether we could tax the aircraft and I think that's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is it possible to distinguish the aircraft from the taxation and the containers here so that we could affirm the decision of the Supreme Court of California and yet nonetheless not foreclose the question of the taxability of the aircraft?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Rehnquist I think so.

The aircraft, I hate to use this touching language, but the aircraft do come into only one place in the taxing jurisdiction and that place is covered by well like the New York airport authority, Los Angeles has the same sort of thing and is covered by airport fees.
When the container comes in here, the fee in the port is imposed on the vessel whether it has containers or not.

When the containers come here they put the in and through and to destinations and from destinations throughout the taxing jurisdiction and that gives you the assurance I believe that the benefits and protections and the tax relationship is there, whereas with the airplane perhaps that benefits and tax relationship is a little bit more conjectural, simply just hard.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Mr. Clark if you are right and you could tax the aircraft, I take it if Japan airlines has scheduled stop at Los Angeles.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes Sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And another scheduled stop at Chicago and another scheduled stop at New York, at (Inaudible) that Illinois and New York could also tax the aircraft?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: That's correct Mr. Justice Brennan.
They could indeed, but only in sense of its apportioned presence.
We are not going –

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Presence of what?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Only in keeping with its apportioned presence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could you also tax the trains that stop at each place?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, we do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You could?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the Pullman, what about the Pullman case?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: The Pullman case has been followed by every state imposing personal property taxes ever since its inception, yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you put the trains and planes on the same level?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Sir, I think the difference between --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I should take a whole lot of weight, you are only talking about -- this case only involves containers?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Yes Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: [Inaudible] ships and everything else, how far you going?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, I think that there are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: [Inaudible] just a container point [Inaudible] decided by this Court?

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: I believe that it can be decided that way Mr. Justice Marshall, that's correct and I don't mean to assert or push anybody Mr. Justice Marshall, but what I'm saying in essence is that the apportionment doctrine logically applies to the benefits and protections conferred to all of these instrumentalities.
If as I say, the port authority and these things follows.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You won't be satisfied that we just stop on containers.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: Oh no sir, I'll be satisfied.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it wasn't your idea to make this broad argument, you are simply trying to answer the questions from members of the Court.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: That is correct Mr. Justice Stewart and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I started it.

turn.speaker: james_dexter_clark
turn.label: Mr. James Dexter Clark
turn.text: [Attempt to Laughter] The home port doctrine then deals with the exceptions to it and the argument regarding the home port doctrine deals with that exception by means of apportionment.

The friendship, commerce and navigation treaty stands I believe soundly for the proposition that both national treatment and apportionment are the expectations which the appellants received when they came here.

There are many treaties involving prevention of double taxation with regard to federal income taxes and the like and the friendship commerce and navigation treaties I believe were intended to fill a general rule as to all other taxes including state and local taxes which are specifically mentioned there in and in which in essence show that the national treatment and the very idea of apportionment are encountered by the people who involved in negotiating that treaty and accepted both.
So I think the enactments of the executive and of the federal government indicate that this tax is proper.

The container convention contains no explicit language and as I say if we contend that the taxation by reason of importation means that this tax is covered by that language that all taxes are covered by that language.
Thank you Mr. Justice, thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
